title: What AFR readers think of Afterpay, superannuation and interest rates
text:
The majority of Australian Financial Review readers oppose the "buy now, pay later" lender Afterpay's contentious policy which stops retailers from passing on credit card surcharges to customers, according to our reader poll.

A survey of 439 readers revealed they opposed Afterpay's policy, which faces closer scrutiny from a Reserve Bank of Australia investigation into "pay later" operators blocking merchants from passing costs to customers - something not available to the traditional credit card schemes.

Asked whether surcharges of about 3-7 per cent should be passed on to customers, as is the case with American Express cardholders, 52 per cent of readers agreed, 37 per cent disagreed and 11 per cent were undecided.

Eighty per cent of respondents were aged 18 to 64, the remainder were over 65, and almost two-thirds were male.

Readers were asked for their views on interest rates after Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe said he was confident the economy was improving and that the chances of another rate cut in November had faded.
description: AFR readers oppose Afterpay's policy of blocking retailers from passing on transaction costs and side with seniors accusing the government of profiteering.
